title: Shares in G4S fall after broker downgrade
text:

Fri, Aug 14, 2015, 02:44 BST - UK Markets open in 5 hrs 16 mins Shares in G4S fall after broker downgrade By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 7 hours ago 4.605 0.000 
Goldman Sach downgrades G4S (Copenhagen: G4S.CO - news ) amid concerns of a slowdown in emerging markets and aggressive competitive in the security sector. 
G4S could not protect itself from hefty losses yesterday, as brokers downgraded the stock amid concerns of a slowdown in emerging markets and aggressive competition in the security industry. 
The group, which stocks ATMs, runs prisons and protects airports, became the biggest laggard on the FTSE 100 after Goldman Sachs (NYSE: GS-PB - news ) slashed its target price to 260p from 300p and lowered its rating to “sell” from “neutral”, one day after it published its half-year results. 
The fall was more than enough to erase a 1.2pc gain on Wednesday, when the firm posted a 4.9pc rise in h alf-year adjusted operating profit to £193m , boosted by large contracts in Asia and the Middle East. 
Goldman Sachs analysts said the security solutions industry is becoming a fiercely competitive environment. “Disruptive technologies are changing the competitive dynamics for an already challenged industry, creating opportunities for new players while driving up capital intensity of the man-guarding business,” said Daria Fomina of Goldman Sachs. 
The bank also reckons economic pressures in Africa and Latin America, which are likely to continue to depress growth rate for the company, will become visible in G4S’s second-half results. 
Exane BNP Paribas also lowered its rating to “neutral”. Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in the company, whose reputation was tarnished when it failed to deliver security at the London Olympics in 2012, closed 14.5p, or 5.4pc, lower at 255.4p. 
In the broader market, equities bounced back after the People’s Bank of China (HKSE: 3988-OL.HK - news ) attempted to ease investor concerns by claiming there was no further basis for further depreciation of the currency. However, David Madden of IG (LSE: IGG.L - news ) warned “the move higher in the stock market feels more like bargain hunting rather than a genuine feeling that China’s economy will improve, despite its overnight bounce”. 
The CAC in Paris jumped 1.3pc, while the German DAX advanced 0.8pc. Despite making gains in early trade, the FTSE 100 was dragged lower in the afternoon, closing 2.86 points lower at 6,568.33. * How China devalued the yuan for the first time in two decades, and why it matters CocaCola Hellenic Bottling Company became the darling of the FTSE 100, climbing 97p to £14.20, after half-year results impressed investors . Volumes grew by 3.8pc, with strong performances from Nigeria, Romania and Ukraine more than offsetting the weakness in Russia. Only last week, Goldman Sachs downgraded the drinks bottler, citing a subdued consumer environment in Russia and Nigeria. 
TUI AG (LSE: TUI.L - news ) also recorded significant gains, up 69p to £11.14, as third-quarter pre-tax profits rose by 18pc to £194m . Despite the impact of the terror attacks in Tunisia earlier in the summer, which wiped €10m off earnings, the group said full-year profit growth would come in at the upper end of its guidance. 
However, Mike van Dulken, of Accendo Markets, warned “uncertainty remains over the other favourite Greece, with performance hindered by painful bail-out negotiations, a referendum and imposition of painful capital controls”. 
Elsewhere, a number of stocks were hit by trading ex-dividend. Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) , which has also been bruised by falling commodity prices, slipped 95.5p to £24.59, BG Group (LSE: BG.L - news ) fell 20p to £10.80, Pearson (Xetra: 858266 - news ) lost 15p to close at £11.51 and Diageo (LSE: DGE.L - news ) slid 13p to £17.62. On the mid-cap index Greene King (Other OTC: GKNGY - news ) lost 21p to finish at 845.5p, while Berkeley Group was off by 59p. 
Equipment rental group Ashtead , which was also trading ex-dividend, was knocked as two brokers revised its target price downwards. UBS (NYSEArca: FBGX - news ) revealed, through its research team Evidence Lab, the level of competition Ashtead faces in the United States. 
The bank reckons the average Sunbelt branch, which Ashtead acquired in 1990, faces competition from around 12 other branches within a 30 minute drive, whereas its rival United Rentals (NYSE: URI - news ) has only 2.8 branches in the same radius. Rory McKenzie, of UBS, said “we struggle to believe Ashtead will not be affected by the increase in rental equipment supply and localised demand weakness in the oil and gas markets”. 
Separately, Bank of America Merrill Lynch reduced its target price to 820p from 1,000p due to comments made by rival United Rentals, which pointed to weakening trends in the equipment rental space. Shares fell 27p, or 2.8pc, to 951p. 
Cineworld , 7.4pc better at 589p, enjoyed a blockbuster day, rising to the top of the mid-cap index. Traders were buying into news of double-digit growth in the box office , with Jurassic World, Fifty Shades of Grey and Fast (Shanghai: 600391.SS - news ) and Furious 7 among the strongest titles released in the first half of the year. With half-year pre-tax soaring 74pc to £39.3m, Canaccord Genuity (Other OTC: CCORF - news ) hiked its target to 620p from 540p.
